ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 83-2, adopted March 10, 1983, amended the Code by enacting provisions pertaining to officers and employees and designated as §§ 2-2—2-14. In order to maintain consistency in classification and in order to better facilitate the inclusion of this new material, the editor has redesignated the provisions or Ord. No. 83.2 as §§ 2-4—2-16. Former § 2-16, pertaining to the oath of office for officers of the city and presumably deriving from provisions adopted at the time of initial codification, has been treated as being superseded by similar provisions of Ord. No. 83-2 (see § 2-7). 
Charter reference— Power of mayor and council to choose officers generally, § 9 et seq. 
Cross reference— Personnel management system policies, Ch. 17.1. 
State Law reference— Authority to establish offices, agencies and employments, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2. 

Sec. 2-4. - Definitions. 
As used in this Code, unless context otherwise requires: 
Chief executive or administrator is the mayor or other officer vested with the executive powers of the City of Port Wentworth. 
City is the City of Port Wentworth. 
City council or council is the council or body vested with the legislative powers of the City of Port Wentworth. 
(Ord. No. 83-2, § 2-2, 3-10-83) 
Sec. 2-5. - Mayor or administrator. 
The mayor or administrator shall be the executive and administrative officer of the city government, shall enforce the laws of the city and require the faithful performance of all administrative duties and shall have duties and powers as described herein: 
(a)	Duties. The chief administrator shall have the following duties as enumerated below: 
(1)	Appointment, dismissal, etc. The chief administrator shall appoint competent, qualified officers and employees to the administrative service and shall have the power to dismiss, suspend and discipline, in accordance with the personnel system, all officers and employees in the administrative service under his control, with approval of the mayor and council. they shall also have the power to authorize a department head or officer responsible to him to appoint and remove subordinates serving under the department head or officer with approval of the mayor and council. 
(2)	Appointment to acting capacity. The chief administrator shall designate himself or some other officer or employee to perform the duties of any office or position in the administrative service under his control which is vacant or which lacks administration due to the absence or disability or the incumbent. 
(3)	Annual report. He shall prepare and present to council an annual report of the city's affairs, including a summary or reports of department heads, and such other reports as the council shall require. 
(4)	Budget report. He shall assemble estimates of the financial needs and resources of the city for each ensuing year, and shall prepare a program of activities within the financial power of the city, embodying it in a budget document with proper supporting schedules and analyses. 
(b)	Powers. The chief administrator shall have the following enumerated powers: 
(1)	Assignment according to classification. The chief administrator shall have the power to assign any employee of the city to any department or branch thereof requiring services appropriate to the personnel system classification of the employees so assigned. 
(2)	Prescribed rules. He shall have the power to prescribe such rules and regulations as he shall deem necessary or expedient for the conduct of administrative agencies subject to his authority and he shall have the power to revoke, suspend or amend the rule or regulation of the administrative service by whomever prescribed. 
(3)	Investigate. He shall have the power, either by himself or by any officer or person designated for the purpose by him, to investigate and to examine or inquire into the affairs or operations of any department, division, bureau, or office; and when so authorized by the council, he shall have the power to employ consultants and professional counsel to aid in such investigation, examinations, or inquiries. 
(4)	Override officials. He shall have the power to set aside any action taken by a department head and may supersede him in the functions of his office. All department heads and the supervisors serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor and council. 
(5)	Delegate authority. He shall have the power to direct any department, division or bureau to perform the work for any other department, division or bureau in the event of an emergency and subject to mayor and council subsequent affirmation. 
(Ord. No. 83-2, § 2-3, 3-10-83; Ord. No. 85-7, 8-22-85) 
Sec. 2-6. - Department interorganization. 
The administrative service of the city shall be divided under the administrator into the following departments and heads thereof: 
(a)	Department of Law—City Attorney. 
(b)	Department of Finance—Director of Finance (adm.). 
(c)	Department of Records—City Clerk (adm.). 
(d)	Department of Police—Chief of Police. 
(e)	Department of Fire—Fire Chief. 
(f)	Department of Recreation—Recreation Director. 
(g)	Department of Personnel—City Clerk (adm.). 
(h)	Departments of Public Works, Streets/Roads, Sanitation, and Water Department—Superintendent of Public Works. 
(i)	Department of Vehicle Maintenance—Director of Vehicle Maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 83-2, § 2-4, 3-10-83) 
Sec. 2-7. - Oaths of office. 
(a)	Personnel required to take an oath of office. Each of the following officers and employees in the administrative service shall be required to take an oath of office before entering upon the discharge of his duties, which office shall be prescribed by the person taking it and shall be filed and preserved in the office of the city personnel officer: 
(1)	The department head in each office. 
(2)	Every member of the police department. 
(b)	Form of oath. The form of the oath of office shall be as follows: 
"I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully discharge the duties devolved upon me as ____________ of the City of Port Went-worth; and that I will faithfully discharge all of the duties assigned to me or imposed upon me by the mayor and council of the City of Port Wentworth, the laws of the State of Georgia, and ordinances of the City of Port Wentworth, to the best of my ability, skill and knowledge during my continuance therein, so help me God." 
(Ord. No. 83-2, § 2-5, 3-10-83) 
State Law reference— Official oaths and commissions, O.C.G.A. § 45-3-1. 
Sec. 2-8. - Bonds; required of certain officers. 
The following named city officials shall each, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, get a good and sufficient surety company bond to the city, duly approved by the city attorney, and conditioned upon the faithful performance and discharge of their respective duties, and for proper application payment of all money or properties coming into their hands by the virtues of their office in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00): 
(a)	City administrator; 
(b)	City clerk and all administrative staff; 
(c)	All police officers; 
(d)	Recreation director. 
(Ord. No. 83-2, § 2-6, 3-10-83) 
Sec. 2-9. - Administrative policy and procedures. 
(a)	Officers; performed duties. Officers shall perform all duties required of his office by state law, the Charter, this Code, and ordinances of the city, and such other duties not in conflict therewith as may be required by the administrator. 
(b)	Department heads. The head of departments shall: 
(1)	Responsibility to administrator. Be immediately responsible to the administrator for effective administration of their respective departments in all activities assigned thereto. 
(2)	Inaugurate sound practices. Keep informed as to the latest practices in their field and shall inaugurate such new practices as appear to be a benefit to the service and to the public. 
(3)	Report to administrator. Submit quarterly and annual reports of the activities of his department to the administrator. 
(4)	Maintain records. Establish and maintain a system of filing and indexing records and reports in sufficient detail to furnish all information necessary to proper control of departmental activities and to form a basis for the periodic reports to the administrator. 
(5)	Authority over employees. Have power, when authorized by the mayor and council, to appoint and remove, subject to the personnel system regulations for personnel, all subordinates under him in accordance with all federal and state laws. 
(6)	Maintain equipment. Be responsible for the proper maintenance of all city property and equipment used in his department. 
(c)	Departments. Each department shall cooperate with other departments, and furnish, upon the direction of the administrator, any other department such service, labor and materials as may be requisitioned by the head of such department, and as his own facilities permit, through the same procedure and subject to the same audit and control as other expenses are incurred. 
(d)	Operation of administrative service. All units in the administrative service shall: 
(1)	Office hours. Be open between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on weekdays, and shall be closed Saturday and legal holidays. 
(2)	Make daily deposits. Make a daily deposit with treasurer of any money received directly from the public. 
(3)	Payment of monies. Pay out monies belonging to the city only in the manner prescribed herein. 
(Ord. No. 83-2, § 2-7, 3-10-85; Ord. No. 85-6, 8-22-85) 
Sec. 2-10. - Department of law. 
The department of law shall consist of the city attorney who shall enforce all laws and acts to protect the interest of the city and who shall: 
(1)	Advise council. Advise council or its committees or any city officer, when thereto requested, upon all legal questions arising in the conduct of the city business. 
(2)	Prepare ordinances. Prepare or revise ordinances when so requested by council or any committee thereof. 
(3)	Give opinions. Give his opinion upon any legal matter or question submitted to him by the council, or any committees or by any city officer. 
(4)	Attend council meetings. Attend all council meetings in their entirety for the purpose of giving council any legal advice requested by its members. 
(5)	Prepare legal instruments. Prepare for execution all contracts and instruments to which the city is a party, and shall approve, as to form, all bonds required to be submitted to the city. 
(6)	Prosecute offenders and defend officials. Prepare, when authorized by the council, all charges and complaints against and to appear in the appropriate courts in the prosecution of every person charged with a violation of a city ordinance or any regulation adopted under the authority of the Charter, or with the commission of a misdemeanor as declared by the Charter or by virtue of his authority. In any prosecution for violation of any regulation adopted by any board or commission created under the authority of the Charter, the city attorney shall act under the direction of such board or commission, subject to such paramount control as given to the council by the Charter. 
(7)	Settlement of claims. Have the power to adjust, settle, compromise, or submit to arbitration any action, causes of action, accounts, debts, claims, demands, disputes and matters of favor of or against the city or in which the city is concerned, provided the money to settle claims has generally been appropriated and is available therefor. 
(8)	Make reports: 
(a)	Immediate report of decision. Immediately report the outcome of any litigation in which the city has an interest to the administrator and council. 
(b)	Annual report of pending litigation. Make an annual report to the administrator and council, as of the first day of July of each year, of all pending litigation in which the city has an interest and the condition thereof. 
(9)	Control legal services incidental to council action. Has charge of all legal services auxiliary to Council action in connection with the appropriating of property to public use and the levy of assessments. 
(10)	Workmen's compensation. Prepare and approve all workmen's compensation payrolls and shall investigate all cases in which workmen's compensation is involved and be responsible for the filing of all documents and papers required by the Workmen's Compensation Act of the state. 
(11)	Keep records: 
(a)	Suits. Keep a complete record of all suits in which the city has or had an interest giving the names of the parties, the court where brought, the nature of the action, the disposition of the case, or its condition if pending, and the briefs of council. 
(b)	Opinions and titles. Keep a complete record of all written opinions furnished by him and of all certificates or abstracts or certain title furnished by him to the city, or any department or official thereof. 
(12)	Deliver records to successor. Deliver all records, documents, and property of every description in his possession belonging to his office or to the city to his successor and office who shall give him duplicate receipts therefor, one (1) of which he shall file with the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 83-2, § 2-8, 3-10-83) 
Sec. 2-11. - Department of finance. 
(a)	Duties of director. In all cases where the duty is not expressly charged to any other department or office, it shall be the duty of the director of finance to act, to promote, secure and preserve the financial and property interests of the city. The director of finance shall: 
(1)	Fiscal supervision over officers, examination of books, report of delinquent payments and financial reports. Exercise the general supervision over all officers of the city regarding the proper management of the fiscal concerns of their respective offices. Examine the books of each department from time to time, and see that they are kept in proper form. See that officers receiving money pay the same into the city treasury, when thereto required, and that all necessary financial reports are made by officers, and shall report all delinquence in such payments or reports to the administrator and council. 
(2)	Responsibility for proceeds of bond. Deposit the proceeds of all sale of bonds with the city treasury immediately after he shall receive same, and until such deposit he shall be responsible for the amount thereof. 
(3)	Duty upon default of officer. Report the default of any officer of the city to the administrator, who shall direct the city attorney to take immediate legal measures for the recovery of the amount for which such officer may be in default. 
(4)	Payment of money from special trust funds. Pay out to persons duly entitled thereto, on warrant of the director of finance, without appropriation by the council, any monies paid into the treasury pursuant to condemnation proceedings, or for the redemption of property sold for taxes, arising from special assessments for public improvements, park fund certificates, condemnation proceedings, or for the redemption of property sold for taxes, arising from special assessments for public improvements, and all special trust funds. 
(b)	Divisions of the department of finance. The department of finance shall be divided into the following divisions and supervisors thereof: 
(1)	Division of the treasury. Supervised by the city treasurer, who shall: 
a.	Accounts of receipts and expenditures. Keeping proper books, a full and accurate account of all the money received and disbursed by him in behalf of the city, specifying the time of receipt and disbursement, from whom received and to whom disbursed, and on what account received and disbursed and how paid. 
b.	Cancellation of evidences and debts. Cancel all warrants and other evidences of debt against the city, on whatever paid by him, by stamping or writing across thereof the words, "Paid by the City Treasurer," with the date of payment written or stamped thereon. 
c.	Receive and disburse monies. Receive and have custody of all money paid to the city and shall disburse city monies upon the warrant of the director of finance. 
d.	Pay city employees. Pay city employees upon the presentation of the properly certified payroll. 
e.	Collect monies and fees due the city. Demand and receive all monies and fees owing to the city whenever any person is indebted to the city in any manner, and the means of collection of such debt is not otherwise provided for by law. When any claim shall not be collectable by other methods he shall report the same to the city attorney for prosecution. 
f.	Daily settlement with director of finance. Make a daily settlement with the director of finance of the amounts received and paid out during the day for which settlement is being made, and at such settlement shall deliver to the director of finance proper accounts for all warrants and other obligations of the city paid by him since his last settlement and shall take a receipt therefor, in duplicate, one (1) to be turned over to the director of finance and one (1) to be retained by him, and once each month he shall balance accounts with the director of finance, which monthly settlement shall show the balance to the credit of the several funds for which the treasurer is responsible. 
g.	Permits and licenses. Issue all permits and licenses except those which are required by ordinance to be issued by a particular department or office. 
h.	Monthly reports to the director of finance. Make a detailed report to the director of finance, on the first day of each month, as to the business of his office during the month preceding, showing the balance on hand to the credit of the different funds at the time of his last report, the amounts received during the month, and on what account, together with such other items or facts as the director of finance may require. 
(2)	Divisions of accounts. Headed by the city clerk, whose duties shall be as follows: 
a.	Audit accounts. Examine and audit the accounts of all officers of the department subject to the approval of the administrator and council. 
b.	Prescribe form. Prescribe the form of accounts and reports to be rendered to him. 
c.	Certify contracts. Certify, according to law, all contracts, agreements, or other obligations for the expenditure of public funds entered into by any official of the city government, and no such contract, agreement, or other obligations shall be valid until so certified by him. 
d.	Budget duties. Prepare estimates of revenue, and shall give such assistance in preparation of the budget as may be required of him by the administrator. 
e.	Financial statements. Transmit to the administrator at least semi-monthly audited statements of cash on hand and of classified unencumbered appropriation balances for the city as a whole, and such other financial statements as the manager may from time to time require. He shall keep all departments, boards, commissions, or other institutions currently informed of its classified unencumbered appropriation balances. 
f.	Keep accounts. Keep all general accounts of the city government and of the respective departments, offices, boards, commissions, and institutions thereof. 
g.	Custodian of bonds, contracts, etc. Be charged with the custody of the official bonds of city employees, and with the custody of all deeds, mortgages, contracts, judgments, notes, debts, and choses in action. He shall keep and administer all securities, bonds, or other forms of negotiable instruments owned by or belonging to the city. 
(3)	Division of assessments and tax collection. The duties of the division of assessments and tax collection shall be as enumerated hereafter: 
a.	Assessments and tax rolls and notices. Prepare all work in connection with assessments of property and the preparation of all assessments and tax rolls and tax notices. 
b.	Serve as real estate agent. Act as real estate agent, supervise the lease, rental, or other use in the maintenance of all city property not used by other units of the city. 
c.	Supervision of division of tax collection. Supervise the division of tax collections who shall collect all taxes in the manner authorized or prescribed by law. 
(4)	Division of licenses. The functions and duties of the division of licenses shall be as set out in general licensing ordinances. 
(5)	Division of records. The department of records shall consist of the city clerk, who shall have the following duties: 
a.	Clerk of council. Serve as clerk of council and perform such other duties of a like nature as shall be required by the body. 
b.	Keep records of council. Be responsible for recording, filing, indexing, and safekeeping of all proceedings of council. 
c.	Record ordinances. Record in full, uniformly and permanently, all ordinances and shall authenticate the same. 
d.	Publish council action. Publish daily all adopted ordinances and resolutions of the council, and all legal notices required by law or ordinance. 
e.	Keep election records. Keep and maintain all election records and have custody of all property used in connection with elections. 
f.	Keep vital statistics. Prepare, attest, and report on the vital statistics of the city. 
g.	Notice of expiration of term. Notify the appointing authority of the impending expiration of the term of office of any board or commission member, said notice to be given at least thirty (30) days before such expiration. 
h.	Keep the official seal. Be the custodian of the official seal of the city. 
(Ord. No. 83-2, § 2-9, 3-10-83) 
Sec. 2-12. - Department of public safety. 
(a)	The mayor and council shall have the authority to elect a director of public safety, who shall have command over the police and fire departments of the City of Port Wentworth, and to fix the compensation and terms and conditions of employment and the duties of any such person so employed. The director shall have the authority to fill any public safety positions created by the mayor and council. 
(b)	Department of police. The director of public safety shall direct the police work of the city, be responsible for the enforcement and maintenance of law and order and shall assign officers to areas of responsibilities which he finds as being necessary, i.e. investigation, traffic, records. Reassignments in any of these assignments shall only be by the director of public safety. 
(1)	Divisions. The department of police shall be divided into the following divisions: 
a.	Records division. The director shall supervise this division and has charge of: 
1.	The central complaint desk and dispatching of police records; 
2.	Criminal and noncriminal identification; 
3.	The identification of property; 
4.	The custody of property; and 
5.	The operation of the detention of individuals and an area for detention. 
b.	Investigation. The director shall or may delegate the authority of: 
1.	The investigation of crimes; 
2.	The elimination of illegal liquor traffic and vice; 
3.	The preparation of evidence for the prosecution of criminal cases; and 
4.	Use of the crime laboratory identification, identification of photographs. 
c.	Crime prevention. The director shall be in charge or shall delegate the authority to: 
1.	The prevention and control of juvenile delinquency; 
2.	The handling of cases in which women are involved; 
3.	Crime hazards; and 
4.	The coordination of community agencies interested in crime prevention. 
d.	Traffic division. The director shall or may delegate authority of: 
1.	Control of traffic; 
2.	Traffic education programs; 
3.	School patrols; and 
4.	The coordination of traffic accident prosecution. 
(c)	Department of fire. 
(1)	The director of public safety shall be charged with prevention of fire and protection of life and property against fire and shall: 
a.	Report losses. Report all fire losses to the city administrator. 
b.	Maintain equipment. Be responsible for the maintenance care of all property and equipment used by his department. 
(2)	Divisions of the department of fire. The fire department of the City of Port Wentworth shall be divided into divisions and supervisors thereof by the director of public safety in accordance with the rules and regulations set forth within the department. 
(Ord. No. 12-06, § 1, 3-22-12) 
Sec. 2-13. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-06, § 1, adopted March 22, 2012, repealed § 2-13, which pertained to the department of fire. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 2-14. - Department of public works, streets/roads, sanitation, and water department. 
(a)	The director of public works shall be responsible for all matters relating to the construction, management, maintenance, and operation of the physical properties of the city. The department of public works shall be divided under the director of public works into the following divisions and bureaus and supervisors thereof: 
(1)	Division of water and sewer maintenance, which shall construct, operate, and maintain the city water distribution and sewer systems. 
(2)	Divisions of parks, which shall operate and maintain all city parks except that the recreational area and facilities shall be under the supervision of the director of recreation. 
(3)	Division of signal service, which shall construct, install, repair, and maintain all facilities of the fire, traffic-control signals and other electrically operated signals but excluding the police radio system. The services of this division shall be available to other departments when so ordered by the administrator. 
(b)	The director of public works shall direct the collection of all garbage and rubbish, operate the city dump, clean and improve streets, maintain and provide for adequate drainage on all streets, sidewalks, and bridges. He shall operate and maintain all municipal off-street parking lots and areas and such other things as shall be required by the administrator. 
(Ord. No. 83-2, § 2-12, 3-10-83) 
Sec. 2-15. - Department of vehicle maintenance. 
The director of vehicle maintenance shall: 
(1)	Direct the repair and maintenance of all city vehicles; 
(2)	Keep records of all machinery, vehicles, motors, etc., for cost control and inventory. 
(3)	Operate the municipal garage and shall maintain and provide for city uses all automotive equipment owned by the city as well as gas and oil, and shall have charge of the city's radio plant and equipment maintenance, and such other things as shall be required by the administrator. 
(Ord. No. 83-2, § 2-13, 3-10-83) 
Sec. 2-16. - Department of recreation. 
The director of recreation shall plan, promote, organize, and supervise a comprehensive municipal recreation program and administer the same in the interest of the entire community and shall furnish to the administrator monthly reports and fund accounting. Other duties of the director of recreation are: 
(1)	Supervise recreation areas. Supervise recreational use of playgrounds, playfields, recreation centers, swimming pools, ball diamonds, and such other recreation areas and facilities as may be available to carry out the city's recreation program. 
(2)	Conduct community activities. Conduct and supervise any form of recreational, cultural, or social activity that will employ the leisure time of the citizens in a wholesome and constructive manner. 
(Ord. No. 83-2, § 2-14, 3-10-83) 
Sec. 2-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-1, adopted July 24, 1980, repealed § 2-17, pertaining to certain city officials being deemed peace officers. Former § 2-17 was derived from Ord. No. 73-1, §§ 1—4, adopted Feb. 22, 1973. 
Sec. 2-18. - Conflicts of interest in purchasing. 
All officials and appointed officials are deemed subject to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-67A et seq., shall make the disclosures therein required, and shall be subject to the penalties therein stated. In addition, any official or appointed official required to make the disclosures set forth in the aforesaid provisions of the Georgia Code shall be prohibited from participating in the zoning matter in which he or she has a direct or indirect interest. A violation of the aforesaid provisions of Georgia Code shall also constitute a violation of this Code. The disclosure requirements set forth in O.C.G.A. § 36-67A and the prohibition from participation imposed in this paragraph shall also pertain to all officials and appointed officials who are involved in the process of approving and/or disapproving residential and commercial subdivision plats. 
(Ord. No. 87-12, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 2-19. - Conflicts of interest in contracts. 
It shall be unlawful for any officer of the council or any person holding any appointment under the council, with any salary annexed thereto, to be concerned, directly or indirectly, in any contract with the council, or its agents or officers, or in any contract or engagement of a pecuniary character in which the city is either directly or indirectly concerned. Any person violating this section may be dismissed from office by the council, in addition to any other penalty provided in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 87-12, 11-12-87) 
Secs. 2-20—2-28. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-29. - Voter registration to be local. 
The city shall maintain its own registration for voters in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 34A-501(b). 
(Ord. No. 74-6, § 2, 6-27-74) 
Sec. 2-30. - Voter registration date. 
Any citizen of the city desiring to vote shall register at the city hall; the closing date for registration shall be thirty (30) days prior to the election day. 
(Ord. No. 74-6, § 4, 6-27-74)

Sec. 2-31. - Candidates' qualifying date; election date. 
(a)	Each candidate desiring to have his or her name on the ballot shall file notice of his or her candidacy in the city hall. 
(b)	In the case of a general election held in an odd-numbered year, the municipal qualifying period shall commence no earlier than 8:30 a.m. on the second Monday in September immediately preceding the general election and shall end no later than 4:30 p.m. on the following Friday; the election shall be held on the Tuesday following the first Monday in November of each odd-numbered year. 
(Ord. No. 74-6, § 3, 6-22-74; Ord. No. 91-4, 3-28-91; Ord. No. 01-15, 8-23-01)

ARTICLE IV. - RECORDER'S COURT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Police court, § 31 et seq. 
State Law reference— Municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-42. - Established. 
The recorder's court of the City of Port Wentworth is hereby established. 
(Ord. No. 57-9, § 1, 5-30-97) 
Sec. 2-43. - Court costs and charges. 
(a)	Any person against whom a fine is imposed by the municipal court of the City of Port Wentworth, formerly known as the recorder's court of the City of Port Wentworth, for the violation of any of the laws or ordinances of the city or of the laws of the State of Georgia shall be subject to court costs in the amount of thirty dollars ($30.00) per violation. 
(b)	Any person against whom a fine is imposed by the municipal court of the City of Port Wentworth, formerly known as the recorder's court of the City of Port Wentworth, for the violation of any laws or ordinances of the city or of the laws of the State of Georgia shall be subject to additional costs in the amount of thirty dollars ($30.00) per violation to be used for the improvement or enhancement of information technology of the department of police. 
(Ord. No. 03-25, 12-11-03; Ord. No. 11-26, 11-17-11; Ord. No. 12-02, 1-26-12; Ord. No. 16-05, § 1, 5-26-16)
