Chapter 19.1 - SIGNS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 09-06A, §§ 1—22, adopted May 28, 2009, repealed the former chapter 19.1, §§ 19.1-11—19.1-30, 19.1-41—19.1-43, and enacted a new chapter 19.1 as set out herein. The former chapter 19.1 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Sec. 19.1-1. - Purpose and findings. 
Be it ordained by the city council of the City of Port Wentworth, Georgia, that: 
(a)	The mayor and council find that signs provide an important medium through which individuals may convey a variety of messages. However, left completely unregulated, signs can become a threat to public safety as a traffic hazard and detriment to property values and the city's overall public welfare as an aesthetic nuisance. See, e.g., Scenic America, Billboards and Sign Control available at http://www.scenic.org; Jerry Weitz, Ph.D., AICP, The Public Purpose of Roswell's Sign Ordinance and the Implications of Doing Without It: A Position Paper (December 7, 1999) available at http://roswellgov.com; Street Graphics and the Law, 2004 Revised Edition, Daniel Mandelker, Andrew Bertucci, and William Ewald. The City of Port Wentworth's population has grown substantially since the year 2000 census, most significantly in the area of the city to the north of the intersection of State Route 21 and Crossgate Road, as evidenced by the number of building permits issued for residential construction. At the same time the City of Port Wentworth has experienced significant commercial growth, particularly in the vicinity of the I-95 interchange at State Route 21, in the form of hotels, grocery stores, restaurants, and other businesses that serve the residents of the City of Port Wentworth and the motoring public. With the increase in residential and commercial growth has come a drastic and dramatic increase in the volume of traffic in the city. In order to promote public safety, uniform regulation of signs providing directional, commercial, and noncommercial information to the motoring public is essential. Based on the above facts, cited materials and the studies referenced therein, the city finds that unregulated signs may: 
(1)	Be a safety hazard to drivers and pedestrians; 
(2)	Create unsafe, cluttered and aesthetically blighted thoroughfares throughout the city; 
(3)	Hamper economic growth; 
(4)	Lower property values; 
(5)	Adversely impact public investments; 
(6)	Degrade the utility of public safety signs; and 
(7)	Adversely impact the aesthetic quality of the community and surrounding environment. 
(b)	Various and diverse businesses are located within the City of Port Wentworth. The need to advertise products and services must be balanced by the city's obligation to restrict clutter, maintain an aesthetically pleasing environment, protect property values, and enhance public safety. 
(c)	Regulation of the location, size, placement, and certain features of signs is necessary to enable the public to locate goods, services, and facilities in the city without difficulty and confusion, to improve the general attractiveness of the community, to take advantage of the community's natural environment, and to protect property values therein. Such regulation is also necessary to facilitate and aid in the identification and location of businesses in the city in the event of police, fire, or other emergencies and to avoid confusion and delay in response to such emergencies. Accordingly, it is the intention of the city to establish regulations governing the display of signs which will: 
(1)	Balance the rights of individuals to convey their messages through signs and the right of the public to be protected against the unrestricted proliferation of signs; 
(2)	Promote and protect the public health, safety and general welfare; 
(3)	Enhance the economy and the business and industry of the city by promoting the reasonable, orderly and effective display of signs; 
(4)	Restrict signs and lights which increase clutter or which increase the probability of traffic accidents by obstructing vision or distracting motorists; 
(5)	Protect property values by minimizing the possible adverse effects and visual blight caused by signs; 
(6)	Promote signs which are compatible with their surroundings; 
(7)	Afford the business community equal and fair opportunity to advertise and promote its products and services without discrimination; 
(8)	Improve traffic and pedestrian safety; 
(9)	Maintain and enhance the visual environment, and preserve the right of citizens and visitors to enjoy the city's scenic beauty; 
(10)	Promote economic development; 
(11)	Promote the purposes stated in this section by regulating signs based on objective standards, including, but not limited to height and size, and without regard to the content of the sign message; 
(12)	Ensure the fair and consistent enforcement of sign regulations. 
(d)	It is also the purpose of this article to insure proper maintenance, for safety and structural soundness, as well as the appearance and attractiveness of signs. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 1, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-2. - Definitions. 
Aggregate sign area shall mean the area of all signs on a parcel, excluding the area of one (1) face of all double-faced signs. 
Animated sign/changeable copy sign shall mean a sign with action, motion, or changing colors which requires electrical energy. This definition includes any signs that electronically changes the sign face, whether by substitution of copy or scrolling. An electronic sign that maintains a steady sign face without change for no less than six (6) hours is not considered an animated sign. 
Area of a sign/Sign area shall mean the smallest square, rectangle, triangle, circle, or combination thereof, which encompasses one (1) face of the entire sign, inclusive of any border and trim but excluding the base, apron, supports, and other structural members. 
Awning sign shall mean a sign located on a roof-like cover extending before a place as a shelter and which may be used in lieu of a wall sign. 
Billboard sign shall mean any free-standing sign with a sign area exceeding three hundred (300) square feet. 
Double-faced sign shall mean a sign which has two (2) display areas placed back to back against each other or where the interior angle formed by the display areas is sixty (60) degrees or less, where one (1) face is designed to be seen from one (1) direction and the other face from another direction. 
Flag shall mean any fabric or bunting containing colors, patterns, or symbols used to signify a government or other entity or organization. 
Freestanding sign shall mean a sign securely affixed to a support structure which is permanently attached to the ground and wholly independent of any building for support, such as monument or stanchion signs. 
Illuminated sign shall mean a sign that has light cast upon the sign from a source either internal to the sign or from an extemallight source directed primarily toward such sign. 
Monument sign shall mean a freestanding sign mounted directly upon the ground. Such sign may not be attached to or be a part of or supported by the building in or to which the sign applies. 
Non-conforming sign shall mean any sign which does not conform to the provisions of this article that was legal at the time of its erection. 
Parcel shall mean a separate tax unit of real property on county real estate records. 
Roof sign shall mean a sign attached to or supported by the roof of a building or which extends above the immediately adjacent roofline of the building. 
Sign shall mean a device or representation for visual communication which is used for the purpose of bringing the subject thereof to the attention of others. 
Stanchion sign shall mean a freestanding sign mounted on one (1) or more steel poles set in the ground and of sufficient strength and size to support the advertisement portion of such structure which rests upon or is supported by such poles. 
Wall sign shall mean a sign fastened, placed or painted upon or parallel to the exterior wall of the structure itself, whether front, rear or side of the structure. 
Window sign shall mean a sign installed flush with or on a window and intended to be viewed from the outside. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 2, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-3. - Permits. 
(a)	Within the jurisdictional boundaries of the City of Port Wentworth, all signs erected, posted, displayed, or substantially changed on or after the date of enactment of this article shall conform to the provisions of this article. 
(b)	Within the jurisdictional boundaries of the City of Port Wentworth, no sign shall be erected, posted, displayed, or substantially changed without a permit issued by the city, except signs made exempt from the permit requirement by this article. 
(c)	Existing signs that conform to the provisions of this article for which a permit would be required under the provisions of this article must be registered with the city within ninety (90) days of the effective date of this chapter. The information provided for registration will be the same information required in a permit application under section 19.1-4. No permit fee will be required for the registration of existing signs. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 3, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-4. - Application information. 
Applications for sign permits required by this article shall be filed with the city clerk by the sign owner or the owner's agent on forms approved by the city administrator. The application shall describe and set forth the following: 
(a)	The type of sign to be erected, the area of the sign, the height of the sign, the shape of the sign, and an explanation of how the sign is to be mounted or erected. 
(b)	The value of the sign. For the purpose of this section, "value" shall include the cost of construction of the sign and structure, plus the cost of materials, including the cost of the structure of the sign. 
(c)	A survey/map to scale showing the street address and property identification number. ("PIN") of the property upon which the subject sign is to be located, the proposed location of the subject sign on the subject property, the distance of the proposed sign from the subject property's boundaries and all existing structures or buildings on the subject property. For billboard sign applications, the following additional requirements shall apply: (1) the survey/map shall also show the geographic coordinates (latitude/longitude) of the subject sign's proposed location; (2) the survey/map is to be provided to the city in a digital format (AutoCAD) and included as part of the submitted application. The digital survey/map should be in a projected coordinate system (preferably State Plane Coordinate System, North American Datum (NAD) 83 Georgia East. Any application failing to submit the digital survey will be considered incomplete by the city and will not be reviewed or considered until all relevant files are received. 
(d)	For billboard sign applications, a survey to scale showing the proposed location of the subject billboard sign and the location(s) of all existing billboard signs within two thousand (2,000) feet of the proposed location of the subject sign; provided that for animated billboard sign applications, the survey shall show, in addition to all existing billboard signs within two thousand (2,000) feet of the proposed location of the sign, all animated billboard signs within five thousand (5,000) feet of the proposed location of the sign. 
(e)	The aggregate area of all signs located on the property on which the subject sign is to be located. The information provided shall include signs which have been permitted but not constructed. 
(f)	The square foot area per sign and the aggregate square foot area if there is more than one (1) sign face. 
(g)	Sign details, including a scaled elevation of the size and height of the proposed sign from ground level and adjacent street level and proposed color scheme of sign. 
(h)	The name of the road and direction of travel from which the sign(s) can be seen. 
(i)	The distance of the sign from the closest adjacent sign in either direction. 
(j)	The name(s) and address(es), of the owner(s) of the real property upon which the subject sign is to be located. 
(k)	Written consent of the owner of the property, or his/her agent granting permission for the placement, maintenance, size and height of the subject sign to be placed on the property. 
(l)	The size of the parcel on which the sign is to be placed. 
(m)	For wall signs: Two (2) sets of building elevations. 
(n)	The name, address, telephone number and business license number of the sign contractor. 
(o)	If the sign is electrical, an electrical permit and the name, address, telephone number and business license number of the electrician. 
(p)	For all signs with a sign area sixteen (16) square feet or larger, or signs ten (10) feet in height or greater, a construction plan certified and stamped by a Georgia registered professional engineer showing compliance with the International Building Code. Said plan shall include, but not be limited to, items required in Chapter 1 and Appendix H, Section H105 of the International Building Code, and show all structural supports. 
(q)	For all signs with a sign area fifty (50) square feet or larger a photographic simulation or sketch rendering of the sign. 
(r)	The zoning district in which the subject property is located and a statement whether all requirements of the zoning district have been complied with. 
(s)	The character area, as identified on the future development strategy land use map, adopted by the mayor and council of the City of Port Wentworth on October 23, 2008, and as amended thereafter, of the property on which the sign is to be located. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 4, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-5. - Time for consideration. 
The city administrator shall process all sign permit applications within thirty (30) business days of the city's actual receipt of a completed application and accompanying sign permit fee. The clerk shall give notice to the applicant of the decision of the city by hand delivery or by mailing the notice, by first class mail, to the address on the permit application on or before the 30th business day after the city's receipt of the completed application and fee. If mailed, notice shall be deemed to have been given upon the date of mailing in conformity with this section. If the city fails to act within the thirty (30) business day period, the permit shall be deemed to have been granted. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 5, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-6. - Denial and revocation. 
(a)	Procedure. The city shall deny permits to applicants that submit applications for signs that do not comply with the provisions of this article, incomplete applications, or applications containing any false material statements. Violation of any provision of this article will be grounds for terminating a permit granted by the city for the erection of a sign. Should it be determined that a sign permit was issued pursuant to an incomplete application or an application containing a false material statement, or that a permit has been erroneously issued in violation of this article, the clerk shall revoke the permit. Should the city deny a permit, the reasons for the denial are to be stated in writing and mailed by first class mail or via hand delivery to the address on the permit application on or before the 30th business day after the city's receipt of the application. Any application denied and later resubmitted shall be deemed to have been submitted on the date of resubmission, instead of the date of the original submission. No permit shall be denied or revoked, except for due cause as hereinafter defined. "Due cause" is the violation of the provisions of this article, state or federal law related to signs, or the submission of an incomplete application or an application containing false material statements. 
(b)	Appeal from decision of city administrator. An individual whose permit application has been denied or a permittee whose permit has been revoked may appeal the decision of the city administrator to the zoning board of appeals upon the filing of a written notice of an appeal with the city clerk within ten (10) business days of the decision. The applicant shall be given ten (10) days written notice of the time, place and purpose of the hearing, with a statement of the reason for the denial of the permit application, or the revocation of a permit. Such appeal shall be considered by the zoning board of appeals at the next zoning board of appeals meeting held after the city's receipt of the written notice of appeal, provided that notice of appeal is received a minimum of ten (10) full business days before the meeting. If the appeal is not heard at such meeting, it shall be heard at the next regular meeting of the zoning board of appeals thereafter. The zoning board of appeals shall make a written final decision no later than thirty (30) days from the date of the hearing. 
(c)	Appeal from decision of the zoning board of appeals. An individual whose permit application has been denied or a permittee whose permit has been revoked may appeal the decision of the zoning board of appeals to the city council upon the filing of a written notice of an appeal with the city clerk within ten (10) business days of the decision. The applicant shall be given ten (10) days written notice of the time, place and purpose of the hearing, with a statement of the reason for the denial of the permit application, or the revocation of a permit. Such appeal shall be considered by the city council at the next city council meeting held after the city's receipt of the written notice of appeal, provided that notice of appeal is received a minimum of ten (10) full business days before the meeting. If the appeal is not heard at such meeting, it shall be heard at the next regular meeting of city council thereafter. The city council shall make a written final decision no later than thirty (30) days from the date of the hearing. 
(d)	Judicial review. In the event an individual whose permit has been denied or revoked is dissatisfied with the decision of the city council, he or she may petition for writ of certiorari to the superior court as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 6, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-7. - Permit expiration. 
A sign permit shall become null and void if the sign for which the permit was issued has not been completed and installed in accordance with the permit application within six (6) months after the date of issuance. The city administrator may grant one (1) extension of time, not to exceed six (6) months, to complete the installation of a sign; provided that such extension is requested, in writing, before the expiration of the six (6) month period following issuance. No refunds will be made for permit fees paid for permits that expired due to failure to erect a permitted sign. If later an individual desires to erect a sign at the same location, a new application must be processed and the fee paid in accordance with the fee schedule applicable at such time. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 7, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-8. - Fees. 
The fee for a permit for a sign other than a billboard sign shall be five dollars ($5.00) per square foot per sign, but in no event less than one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00). The fee for a permit for a billboard sign shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). If electrical inspections are required by codes generally applicable to structures within the jurisdictional limits of the City of Port Wentworth, an electrical inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be added to the fees otherwise due hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 8, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-9. - Prohibited signs. 
The following types of signs are prohibited throughout the city: 
(a)	Animated signs except as provided in subsection 19.1-13(h); 
(b)	Signs on or overhanging public rights of way other than publicly owned or maintained signs; 
(c)	Window signs that exceed fifty (50) per cent of the window area; 
(d)	Signs that contain words, pictures, or statements which are obscene, as defined by the O.C.G.A. § 16-12-80; 
(e)	Signs which simulate an official traffic control or warning sign or hide from view any traffic or street sign, signal or public service sign; 
(f)	Signs which emit or utilize in any manner any sound capable of being detected on any traveled road or highway by a person with normal hearing; 
(g)	Signs which interfere with road or highway visibility or obstruct or otherwise interfere with the safe and orderly movement of traffic; 
(h)	Signs erected by nailing, fastening or affixing the sign in any manner to any tree, post, curve, utility pole, or other structure except as set forth herein; and 
(i)	Signs within one hundred (100) feet of any officially designated historic site or monument, except signs pertaining to that particular site or monument. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 9, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-10. - Restrictions in residential zoning districts. 
Other than subdivision entrance signs allowed under section 19.1-11, parcels located in residential zoning districts shall contain no more than one (1) non-illuminated sign having a sign area no greater than sixteen (16) square feet and shall have a height no greater than five (5) feet as measured from the grade level of the center line of the street adjacent to the parcel on which the sign is to be located. Signs meeting the standards of this section are exempt from permitting requirements. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 10, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-11. - Residential subdivision entrance signs. 
Within a platted residential subdivisions consisting of more than two (2) parcels, no more than two (2) monument signs may be erected at each entrance to the subdivision. Such signs shall not exceed a height of ten (10) feet above the grade level of the center line of the adjacent street and shall not have a sign area greater than one hundred (100) square feet. Such entrance signs shall not count toward the maximum allowable sign area on a residential parcel. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 11, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-12. - Height requirements. 
The following height requirements shall be applicable to signs located in non-residential zoning districts: 
(a)	Stanchion signs, other than billboard signs, shall not exceed fifty (50) in height or a height equal to the distance from the base of the sign to the nearest property line or street right-of-way line, whichever is less, as measured to the top of the highest point on the sign or sign structure. 
(b)	Monument signs shall not exceed ten (10) feet in height. 
(c)	All sign heights shall be measured from the grade level of the center line of the adjacent street to which the property on which the sign is located has access. The level of the ground shall not be altered in such a way as to provide additional sign height. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 12, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-13. - General size and location requirements in non-residential districts. 
(a)	Signs at street intersections. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no freestanding sign may be located: 
(1)	Within twenty (20) feet of the intersection of the extended rights-of-way of city or county streets; or 
(2)	Within one hundred (100) feet of the intersection of the extended rights-of-way of a state highway and another state highway or city or county road. 
(b)	Signs posted without property owner's consent. No sign shall be located on any building, fence or other property belonging to another person without the consent of the owner, and as permitted under the provisions of this article. 
(c)	Billboard signs. 
(1)	Billboard signs shall not exceed six hundred (600) square feet of sign area. Billboard sign faces shall not exceed twelve (12) feet in height or fifty (50) feet in length. 
(2)	Billboard signs shall be located only on parcels: (1) which are zoned commercial or industrial and (2) which are classified as "Transportation and Warehousing" or "Community Gateway" character areas, as identified on the future development strategy land use map adopted by the mayor and council of the City of Port Wentworth on October 23, 2008, and as amended thereafter. 
(3)	Billboard signs shall be located only on parcels adjacent to designated state or federal highways and shall be oriented only towards those highways and shall be located within four hundred (400) feet of the right-of-way of the highway to which it is oriented. 
(4)	No billboard sign shall be located within two thousand (2,000) feet of another billboard sign, measured as a radius, except as otherwise provided under subsection 19.1-10(a) hereunder. 
(5)	No billboard sign shall be located within five hundred (500) feet of any residential zoned parcel. 
(6)	No billboard sign shall be located within five hundred (500) feet of any public park, public playground, public recreation area, public forest, designated historic site, scenic area, or cemetery. 
(7)	No billboard sign shall be erected to a height in excess of eighty (80) feet in height. 
(8)	The number of billboard faces within the corporate limits of the city shall not exceed the number of faces within the corporate limits of the city as of September 30, 2009. An inventory of these existing faces shall be maintained by the office of the city administrator. Billboard permits and applications for permits approved on or before September 30, 2009 shall be counted towards the total number of billboard faces permitted. 
(9)	Billboard signs shall be lighted by down-lighting or otherwise so as not to cast light on adjoining property or shine in such a manner as to cause traffic interference. In no event shall the light source be visible to vehicular traffic from any street or highway. Illumination shall not exceed 20,000 lumen. 
(10)	For the purposes of this section, "interstate interchange" is defined as the intersection of Interstate 95 and GA Highway 21. Billboard signs located adjacent to an interstate interchange are subject to the following additional regulations: 
a.	Up to six (6) billboard signs may be located in each quadrant of the interchange adjacent to and visible from the federal interstate highway. These signs must be located within an area two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet long beginning at a point five hundred (500) feet from the point where the pavement widens on the main traveled way to accommodate the longest entrance or exit ramp. No billboard sign shall be located within five hundred (500) feet of another billboard sign, measured as a radius. The geographical coordinates of the point where the pavement widens on the main traveled way to accommodate the longest entrance or exit ramp to the northeast of the interstate interchange are: 32.196326 latitude/-81.190791 longitude and 32.196075 latitude/-81.190338 longitude. The geographical coordinates of the point where the pavement widens on the main traveled way to accommodate the longest entrance or exit ramp to the southwest of the interstate interchange are: 32.186445 latitude/-81.199103 longitude and 32.186173 latitude/-81.198675 longitude. To the extent the geographical location of the boundary nearest the interstate interchange is different from the written description, the geographic coordinates control. 
(d)	Stanchion signs. 
(1)	The sign area of a stanchion sign to be located on a parcels exceeding three (3) acres shall not exceed three hundred (300) square feet. 
(2)	The sign area of a stanchion sign for a parcel less than three (3) acres, but equal to or greater than thirty thousand (30,000) square feet shall not exceed one hundred and eighty (180) square feet. 
(3)	The sign area of a stanchion sign for a parcel less than thirty thousand (30,000) square feet in size shall not exceed one hundred and forty (140) square feet. 
(4)	Stanchion signs shall be located only on property in commercial or industrial zoning areas and shall be limited to one (1) such sign per parcel per street frontage. 
(e)	Monument signs. Monument signs shall not exceed one hundred (100) square feet of total area, which shall include sign face and structure, and shall be limited to one (1) such sign per parcel per street frontage. 
(f)	Roof signs. Roof mounted signs shall not extend above the peak of the roof nor shall any sign attached to the facade of a building extend more than four (4) feet above the roof line or parapet. 
(g)	Wall and awning signs. 
(1)	Wall and awning signs shall not project above the parapet wall. 
(2)	Wall signs shall not project beyond the building face. Awning signs shall not project beyond the building face by more than four (4) feet. 
(3)	Wall and awning signs shall not exceed a sign area of three hundred (300) square feet or twenty-five (25) percent of the wall face of the premises to which the sign relates, whichever is less, on each street facing wall. 
(4)	Wall and awning signs shall not exceed a sign area of three hundred (300) square feet or fifty (50) percent of the wall face of the premises to which the sign relates, whichever is less, on each wall other than a street-facing wall. 
(5)	The maximum wall or awning sign height shall be ten (10) feet. 
(6)	Wall signs shall only be located on property in commercial or industrial zoning areas. 
(7)	Each building tenant shall be limited to one (1) wall or awning sign on each street-facing wall. 
(h)	Animated signs. 
(1)	Animated or changeable copy signs shall be erected, posted, displayed or modified only in accordance with the criteria hereunder as well as all other generally applicable standards of this article related to the location, height, size, and other characteristics. 
(2)	Each image or message displayed on an animated sign having a sign area greater than sixteen (16) square feet shall remain static for at least ten (10) seconds following the completion of its transition from the previous message. As used in this subsection "static" shall mean fixed, with no portion of the image or message being in motion or changing in color or light intensity as viewed by a person with normal visual acuity. Messages shall not be illuminated by blinking, scrolling, intermittent, or flashing lights. 
(3)	Any change in the image or message of an animated sign having a sign area greater than sixteen (16) square feet shall be substantially instantaneous, two (2) seconds or less, as seen by a person of normal visual acuity, and shall not use fading, rolling, window shading, dissolving or similar effects. 
(4)	No display or other effect from any electronically changed sign shall cause glare or that impairs the vision of the driver of any motor vehicle or otherwise interferes with the safe operation of a motor vehicle. 
(5)	Video technology in digital or electronic message board signs shall use automatic light level controls to reduce light levels at night and under cloudy or other darkened conditions in accordance with the following standards. All digital or electronic message board signs shall have installed ambient light monitors, and shall at all times allow such monitors to automatically adjust the brightness level based on ambient light conditions. Maximum brightness levels for electronic or digital display boards shall not increase by more than 0.3 foot candles over ambient levels. 
(6)	Any animated sign which malfunctions, fails, or ceases to operate in its usual or normal manner causing therein motion, movement, flashing or any other similar effects shall be repaired or disconnected within forty-eight (48) hours by the owner or operator of such sign. 
(7)	No animated billboard sign (for the purpose of this section, "animated billboard sign" is defined as a billboard sign that is animated) shall be placed within two thousand (2,000) feet of another animated sign, said distance to be measured in a radius from the proposed location of the animated sign. 
(8)	An applicant will only be permitted to erect an animated billboard sign within the corporate limits of the city if the applicant removes a number of existing nonconforming billboards that corresponds to a ratio of the respective surface areas of the billboard face. The ratio shall be three to one (3:1), thus requiring the removal of three (3) square feet of existing nonconforming billboard face space for every one (1) square foot of animated sign to be erected. Nonconformity shall be determined by application of the definition of "non-conforming sign" contained in section 19.1-2 of this chapter. Approval of an animated billboard sign permit shall not be granted until the nonconforming billboard faces are removed and the removal is certified by the city administrator or his/her designee. The applicant for an animated sign shall meet all other requirements of the city's ordinances, including the provisions of this chapter. 
(i)	Maximum aggregate sign area. Parcels may contain more than one (1) freestanding sign, provided that: 
(1)	Parcels exceeding three (3) acres shall be allowed a maximum aggregate sign area of three hundred (300) square feet for the entire parcel. 
(2)	Parcels less than three (3) acres but greater than thirty thousand (30,000) square feet shall be allowed a maximum aggregate sign area of one hundred and eighty (180) square feet for the entire parcel. 
(3)	Parcels less than thirty thousand (30,000) square feet in size shall be allowed a maximum aggregate sign area of one hundred and forty (140) square feet for the entire parcel. 
(4)	These limits shall not include the area of any wall signs, window signs or billboard signs located on the parcel. 
(5)	These limits shall include the area of all freestanding signs on the parcel other than billboard signs. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 13, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-14. - Construction standards. 
(a)	All signs for which a permit is required under this article shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the provisions of the city building code. 
(b)	Signs for which a permit is not required under this article that are constructed of degradable material may be posted for a maximum of sixty (60) days unless replaced with another sign of the same material. Any such replacement signs may be posted for a maximum of sixty (60) days. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 14, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-15. - Non-conforming signs. 
(a)	Non-conforming signs which met all legal requirements when erected may stay in place, provided that within ninety (90) days of the effective date of this article the owner of the non-conforming sign or the owner's agent registers the sign with the city. Such registration shall contain the information listed in subsection 19.1-4(a) and shall specify the sign being registered as non-conforming and shall state that the sign was completely installed before the effective date of this article. The payment of a fee is not required for the registration of a non-conforming sign; however, failure to register shall be considered an offense and may be punished as any other ordinance violation. Non-conforming signs shall be permitted until one (1) of the following conditions occurs: 
(1)	The deterioration of the sign or damage to the sign makes it a hazard or unsightly; or 
(2)	The sign has been damaged by circumstances beyond the control of the owner to the extent that more than minor repairs are required to restore the sign; provided that signs damaged by Act of God and not due to the owner's action may be restored to their pre-damaged condition, provided that the useful life of the signs is not extended. 
(b)	No changes in shape, size or design or structural repairs except those permitted pursuant to subsection (a)(2) above shall be permitted, except to make a non-conforming sign comply with all requirements of this article. 
(c)	A non-conforming sign may not be replaced by another non-conforming sign except where changed conditions beyond the control of the owner render the sign non-conforming or warrant the sign's repair. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 15, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-16. - Variances. 
Variances shall be limited to the minimum relief necessary to overcome the hardship. No variance shall be granted to allow a greater number of signs than would be allowed if the hardship did not exist. Variance applications shall be submitted to the board of zoning appeals and shall be heard under the same time frames and rules governing appeals under this article. The recommendation of the board of zoning appeals shall be referred to city council and shall be heard under the same time frame and rules governing appeals under this article. A variance from compliance with the sign regulations of this article shall be limited to the following hardship situations: 
(a)	Standards. 
(1)	Where visibility of a conforming sign from the public street and within fifty (50) feet of the proposed sign would be substantially impaired by existing trees, plants, natural features, signs, existing buildings or structures on a different lot; and 
(2)	Placement of the sign elsewhere on the lot would not remedy the visual obstruction; and such visibility obstruction was not created by the owner of the subject property; and the variance proposed would not create a safety hazard to traffic. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 16, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-17. - Exemptions from permit requirements. 
(a)	The following types of signs shall be exempt from the permit requirements of section 19.1-3 and shall not count towards the maximum aggregate sign area limits provided in sections 19.1-10 and 19.1-13(i): 
(1)	Non-illuminated signs, having a sign area of less than sixteen (16) square feet, provided they are not located in the public right of way. 
(2)	Window signs installed for purposes of viewing from outside the premises. 
(3)	Numerals displayed for purposes of identifying property location and not exceeding four (4) inches in height in residential districts and ten (10) inches in height in nonresidential districts. 
(4)	Seasonal displays located outside of the public right of way that are erected for a maximum period of thirty (30) days no more than twice a year. 
(b)	Every parcel may display no more than two (2) flags that shall not count toward the maximum aggregate sign area limits provided in sections 19.1-10 and 19.1-13(i) without obtaining a permit. Flagpoles in residential zoned districts shall not exceed twenty-five (25) feet in height. Flagpoles in commercial or industrial zoned districts shall not exceed sixty (60) feet in height. The dimensions of any flag shall be proportional to the flagpole height such that the hoist side of the flag shall not exceed fifty (50) percent of the vertical height. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 17, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-18. - Illumination. 
Illumination for signs shall not cast light on adjoining property or shine in such a manner as to cause traffic interference. Illumination, other than internal illumination of digital or electronic message board sign conforming to the requirements of subsection 19.1-13(h), shall be constant and shall not change, flash, scroll or stimulate movement. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 18, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-19. - Insurance requirements 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of erecting or maintaining signs within the city, unless and until such entity obtains and provides the city with a certificate of insurance from an insurance company authorized to do business in the State of Georgia evidencing that the entity has in effect: (a) property damage insurance in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or more per occurrence; and (b) liability insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) or more per occurrence. The certificate of insurance shall state that the insurance carrier will notify the city thirty (30) days in advance of any termination and/or restriction of the coverage. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 19, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-20. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)	All signs shall be maintained in good condition as to present a neat and orderly appearance. The city may, after due notice, issue a citation to any permittee for any sign which shows gross neglect or becomes dilapidated. Such due notice shall be in writing, shall specify the sign and location, and shall state that the sign has not been properly maintained. The city shall give the permittee ten (10) days to rectify the condition or remove the dilapidated sign before issuing a citation. If the permittee fails to correct the deficiencies or remove the sign, the city may have the sign removed at the expense of the permittee. 
(b)	The city may issue a citation for violation of this chapter by any sign erected, altered, converted, or used in violation of this chapter. 
(c)	A violation of this article shall result in the revocation of the sign permit. 
(d)	Any person violating any provision of this article shall be liable for a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each violation. Each day a sign is posted in violation of this article shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 20, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-21. - Vested rights. 
No person applying for a sign permit or erecting a sign under this article shall acquire any vested rights to continue maintenance of such sign. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 21, 5-28-09) 
Sec. 19.1-22. - Non-transferability. 
Sign permits issued pursuant to this article are not transferable. 
(Ord. No. 09-06A, § 22, 5-28-09) 
Chapter 20 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Power of mayor and council over streets, sidewalks and public grounds generally, § 18. 
Cross reference— Street maintenance tax, § 11-91 et seq.; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 13. 
State Law reference— Exceptions to authority, O.C.G.A. § 12-6-24; power and duty of municipality regarding municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90; authority to construct, open, close, or extend public streets, alleys, and sidewalks, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Burning in streets, sidewalks, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to burn or cause to be burned any trash or other thing or substance on any hard-surfaced street or walkway or area within the city without first obtaining a permit. Permits for burning will be issued only for areas zoned R-A located north of Bonnybridge Road. 
(Ord. No. 61-8, § 1, 8-24-61; Ord. No. 99-03, 11-18-99) 
Sec. 20-2. - Display of street numbers. 
All owners or occupants of improved properties including residences, buildings, and other structures which are eligible for numbering for street address purposes shall display appropriate observable numbers on said structures facing the street direction under which they are numbered, so that the structures can be readily identified by said number. 
(Ord. No. 74-9, § 1, 9-26-74) 
Sec. 20-3. - Railroad crossings. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any railroad train, car or engine to remain stationary or standing for longer than the space of ten (10) minutes on any street crossed by a railroad track, or to obstruct in anywise any street crossing for a longer time than ten (10) minutes. 
(b)	Subsection (a) shall not apply in those instances where a road, street or public way is blocked as a result of a derailment, wreck or mechanical failure which renders the train, car or engine totally incapable of operation. 
(Ord. No. 68-5, §§ 1, 2, 4-11-68) 
Sec. 20-4. - Collection of unpaid paving assessments. 
(a)	In each and every instance where any paving assessment obligation owed to the city remains unpaid, in whole or in part, following thirty (30) days from billing, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to issue an execution in the name of the city, in favor of the city, against the defaulting property owner and his property, for the full amount of the assessment owed, plus a ten (10) per cent penalty, plus a five dollar ($5.00) charge for issuing said execution (fi. fa.); an additional charge of up to twenty-five dollars ($25.00) may be assessed by said clerk to cover advertising and administrative expense, and it shall further be provided that an interest charge of six (6) per cent per annum shall accrue against such defaulted property owner and his property, in favor of the city, for the unpaid principal, penalty (fi. fa.) charge, and the advertising and administrative charges. 
(b)	The city clerk shall place execution (fi. fa.) for the assessment owed and due the city into the hand of the chief of police who shall levy upon the property of the defaulting property owner (defendant in execution), and the chief shall sell said land before the city hall after he shall have advertised the time and place of the sale once a week for four (4) weeks in the newspaper published in the county in which sheriff's advertisements are published to the highest bidder therefor for cash, on the first Tuesday of the month following advertisement, within the legal hours of sale. The chief shall execute the necessary deeds and titles to the purchaser of the property at said sale, which deed shall have the force and effect of a sheriff's deed in this state, and he shall apply the proceeds of said sale to satisfy said sums owed to the city by said defaulted property owner (defendant in execution). 
(Ord. No. 70-6, §§ 1, 2, 4-9-70) 
Charter reference— Collection of assessments generally, § 42; street improvements, § 43. 
Sec. 20-5. - Obstructions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to in any way encroach upon or place any obstruction of any kind or nature (including, but not limited to, skateboards, skateboard ramps, etc.) upon any street or sidewalk within the city, or cause the same to be done. Streets and sidewalks shall at all times remain open to the safe use and enjoyment of the public, except that, for the purpose of making needful repairs or other public purpose, the same may be blocked or closed by the mayor or other designated official, who may also issue a permit therefor to builders for placing materials and structures thereon. 
(Ord. No. 88-5, 5-26-88) 
Sec. 20-6. - Removal of obstructions. 
Any obstruction in the streets or sidewalks shall be subject to summary removal by the city, with the aid of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 88-5, 5-26-88) 
Sec. 20-7. - Penalties regarding violation of sections 20-5 and 20-6. 
(a)	Any person who shall molest or interfere with such officers, or either of them, in the removal of obstructions shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 32 of the City Charter. 
(b)	Any police officer upon finding a minor in violation or section 20-5 shall ascertain the name and address of such minor, warn the minor that he/she is in violation of section 20-5, and shall direct the minor to proceed at once to his or her home or usual place of abode. The police officer shall report such action to the chief of the police department, who in turn shall notify the parents, guardian or person having custody or control of such minor. Upon a second violation of section 20-5, the minor shall be turned over to the juvenile courts and dealt with according to the law and procedure dealing with juvenile offenses. 
(Ord. No. 88-5, 5-26-88) 
Secs. 20-8—20-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATION PERMIT AND APPLICATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 07-27, adopted September 27, 2007, repealed the former article II, §§ 20-16—20-28, and enacted a new article II as set out herein. The former article II pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Sec. 20-16. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely discretionary. 
Approved representative —An advocate who represents the director of public services and/or the City of Port Wentworth. 
Applicant —Any person making written application to the director of public services or approved representative for an excavation permit. 
City —The City of Port Wentworth, Georgia, its delegates, and/or employees. 
City limits —The defined limits of a city's area. Formally described as in a state or provincial as being used under the control of the municipal corporation or agency that constitutes the city government. 
Director of public services —Person employed, contracted, or otherwise designated by the City of Port Wentworth for the purpose of coordination, permitting and excavation activities. 
Easement —A right afforded to the City of Wentworth to use another's real property to access the infrastructure for maintenance or construction activities. 
Emergency —Any situation necessitating excavation for the purpose of locating trouble or making repairs in a system for the immediate protection of life, property or the public welfare, or to correct an interruption of utility service. 
Excavation —A hole, trench, ditch, depression or displacement, created on public property, public easements appearing of record or acquired by adverse possession or prescriptive use, right of way, or city limits, resulting from the removal or displacement by a person of pavement, dirt or other materials. 
Excavator —Any person digging, excavating or otherwise conducting work which requires excavation in the City of Port Wentworth's city limits, easements, or right of way pursuant to a valid permit. 
Permittee —One (1) to whom a permission or permit is given. 
Person —Any person or person(s), singular or plural, male or female, natural or artificial, including, but not limited to, a firm partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind, but does not include City of Port Wentworth or its employee's. 
Public utility —Any water, wastewater, reuse water, or storm drain conveyance systems that is owned, maintained, and operated by the city. 
Right of way —Either the area dedicated by plat or deed, or area from curb to curb, or the area of improved surface encompassing the roadway, drainage ditches, and other City of Port Wentworth maintained improvements. 
System —Any pipes, pipeline, tube, main, service, manhole, meter, regulator, valve, conduit, cable, or object of any kind or character whether enumerated herein or not, which is or may be lawfully constructed, left, placed or maintained in, upon, along, across, or under, any property or public easement appearing of record or acquired by adverse possession or prescriptive use. 
Utility —Any person furnishing to the public gas, water service, electricity, sewer service, telephone service, cable television, or similar product or service. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-17. - Excavation permit. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, utility, or other entity. To dig up, break excavate, tunnel, drill, bore, undermine, blast, remove sand, dirt, gravel, or other like materials, to make cause to be made any excavation in or under the surface of any street, sidewalk, curb, or rights of way. To place, deposit, or leave upon any street any earth or excavated materials obstructing or tending to interfere with the free use of the street, within the city limits, unless such person, firm, corporation, utility, or other entity shall first have obtained an application for excavation and the excavation permit authorizing the same and complied with all of the terms of this code. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-18. - Application for permit. 
No excavation permit shall be issued unless written applications for the issuance of an excavation permit on forms provided by the public works department and forms submitted for approval to the director of public services or approved representative. The application shall state the name and address of the applicant, the nature, location, and purpose of the excavation, date of commencement and date of completion of the excavation, and other data as may be reasonably required by the director of public services or approved representative. Application for permit shall be accompanied by two (2) sets of plans showing the extent of the proposed excavation work, the dimensions, and elevations of both the existing ground prior to said excavation and of the proposed excavation surfaces, the locations of the excavation work, and such other information as may be prescribed by the director of public services or approved representative. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-19. - Permit fee. 
Upon submittal of the application for the excavation permit. The applicant shall pay a fifty dollar ($50.00) non-refundable permit fee, to the City of Port Wentworth, to cover reasonable costs for the issuance of the excavation permit. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-20. - Surety bond. 
Before an excavation permit is issued, the applicant shall deposit with the clerk of council or approved representative a surety bond or cashier check in the amount of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) in favor of the city or one hundred and twenty-five (125) per cent of the estimated cost of any excavation(s) and restoration, whichever is greater. 
(a)	With good and sufficient surety by a surety company authorized to do business in the state of Georgia. 
(b)	Satisfactory to the city attorney in form and substance conditioned that the applicant shall secure and hold harmless against any and all claims, judgments, or other cost arising from the excavation permit for which the city, the council, or any city officer may be made liable by reason of any accident or injury to persons or property through the fact of the permittee. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-21. - Exemption from surety bond. 
The provisions of the surety bond shall not apply to any excavation made: 
(a)	Under a contract awarded by the city or made by the city, or to any excavation performed directly by any public utility permitted to operate within the city limits. 
(b)	Franchise or otherwise, for the purpose or supplying natural gas, electric, telephone, cable services. 
(c)	This exception only applies to excavation performed directly by the public utility, and surety bond is required if work is performed by a sub-contractor of any public utility or franchised utility. 
(d)	Excavations required by state, county, or city authorities in connection with the construction or maintenance of roads and highways within their respective rights of way. 
(e)	Excavation by the owner of land for landscaping purposes within the continuous boundaries of such owned premises, provided that the amount of materials moved is less than one (1) cubic yard and no self propelled excavation equipment is used. 
(f)	Repairs of landscaping due to settlement. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-22. - Restoration of right of way, road, and excavated area(s). 
After the completion of the excavation project within the city limits, it shall be the obligation of the permittee to restore the excavated area to "as good" a condition as existing prior to the commencement of the work in the permit. 
(a)	In case of cutting or boring of paved road surfaces, the permittee shall have the responsibility to maintain the repair for a period of two (2) years, excluding, reasonable wear and tear. If, upon notification to the permittee and within fifteen (15) calendar days thereafter, the bore, patch, or other repair has settled, shifted, or otherwise caused an uneven or dangerous condition in the roadway, the permittee shall repair the road surface within fifteen (15) calendar days of the date the permittee receives such notification or make such other arrangements as are mutually agreed by the director of public services and the permittee. 
(b)	In the event the director of public services or approved representative becomes aware of a hazardous or otherwise dangerous condition, existing as a result of an excavation in the city limits. The director of public services or approved representative shall have the authority to take such steps as are necessary to remove or mitigate the hazardous condition. Such remediation will be limited to that reasonably necessary to prevent injury or harm to person or property. As soon as practicable, the director of public services or approved representative shall attempt to contact the responsible party to advise them of the action taken. To the extent the responsible person(s) can be ascertained, the City of Port Wentworth will have the option to precede in accordance with the penalty provisions or seek reimbursement for the cost of the repairs. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-23. - Emergency actions. 
In the event of any emergency in which a main, conduit, or utility facility in or under any street, breaks, burst, or otherwise is in such condition as to immediately endanger the property, life, health, or safety of any individual, the person owning or controlling such main, conduit, or utility without first applying for and obtaining an excavation permit hereunder shall immediately take proper emergency measures to cure or remedy the dangerous conditions for the protection of property, life, health, and safety of individuals. However, such person owning or controlling such facility shall apply for an excavation permit not later than the next business day in which the public works departments office is open for business and shall not proceed with permanent repairs without first obtaining an excavation permit. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-24. - Insurance. 
A permittee, prior to the commencement of excavation work hereunder, shall furnish the director of public services or approved representative satisfactory evidence by documentation that the permittee has in force and will maintain in force during the performance of the excavation work and the period of the excavation permit. Public liability insurance of not less than: 
One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for occurrence. 
One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for general aggregate. 
Three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for property damage. 
Duly issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the State of Georgia and on which policy the city is named as co-insured. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-25. - Inspections. 
The city may elect to inspect each excavation site at times determined appropriate. By applying for a permit under this article, the permittee has agreed to permit and cooperate in such inspections. The permittee and/or owners of any premises in violation of any of the requirements of this article or its permit shall remedy such violations within the time specified by written notice from the city. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-26. - Revocation. 
Excavation permits may be revoked upon violation of any conditions of said permit provided herein or established by the article. Said revocation shall be effective immediately upon written notice of the same by the director of public services or approved representative to the permittee. Upon written demand the permittee may have a hearing before the council at its next available meeting. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-27. - Penalty of violations. 
Any person not giving the notice or securing the permit required by this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or ninety (90) days in jail for each separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Sec. 20-28. - Effect. 
This article shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and publication as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, 9-27-07) 
Secs. 20-29—20-39. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - STREETLIGHTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 04-23, adopted Nov. 18, 2004, deleted §§ 20-62—20-65 and enacted similar provisions to read as herein set out. Former §§ 20-62—20-65 derived from Ord. No. 88-10, adopted Sept. 8, 1988. 

Sec. 20-62. - Purpose. 
This article sets forth criteria for the provision of street lighting along streets to be dedicated to the City of Port Wentworth. 
(Ord. No. 04-23, 11-18-04) 
Sec. 20-63. - Applicability. 
Outdoor lighting shall be required for safety and personal security in single-family and multifamily dwelling unit developments, commercial, industrial, recreational, and institutional developments. 
(Ord. No. 04-23, 11-18-04) 
Sec. 20-64. - Criteria. 
(1)	Illumination levels. 
(a)	Illumination, where required by this article, shall have intensities and uniformity ratios in accordance with the current recommended practices of the Illuminating Engineering Society of North America (IESNA), as from time to time amended. The following table reflects said recommended practices of IESNA at the time of adoption of the within article: 

 
All future amendments to the recommended practices of the IESNA shall be made a part of the Port Wentworth Street Lighting Ordinance without further action by the City of Port Wentworth mayor and council. Copies of IESNA current publications may be obtained from IESNA Publications, 120 Wall Street, New York, NY 10005. 
1.	Fixture design. Fixtures shall be of a type and design appropriate to the lighting application, and aesthetically acceptable to the planning commission for recommendation to the mayor and council. 
2.	Installation. 
a.	Lighting fixtures shall not be mounted in excess of thirty (30) feet above grade. 
b.	Electrical feeds to lighting standards shall run underground, no overhead (on new projects and developments). 
c.	Wood poles are not allowed for illumination of roadways. 
(Ord. No. 04-23, 11-18-04) 
Sec. 20-65. - Plan submission. 
Lighting plans submitted to the municipality for review and approval shall include a layout of the proposed fixture locations; ISO footcandle plots that demonstrate adequate intensities and uniformity; and manufacturer's catalog cuts that present a description of the equipment, including glare reduction devices, lamps, switching devices, mounting heights and mounting methods proposed. All proposed development plans shall, at the time of preliminary plan submittal, include lighting plans indicating proposed placement of all lighting fixtures incorporated with the above referenced specifications. The lighting plans shall also provide an engineering detail of fixtures, manufacturer, model, and installation of same. 
The city engineer shall review the lighting plans for compliance with the ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 04-23, 11-18-04) 
Sec. 20-66. - Street lighting dedication. 
When street lighting is to be dedicated to the City of Port Wentworth, the applicant shall be responsible for all costs involved in the lighting of streets and street intersections from the date the first dwelling is occupied until the date the street is accepted for dedication. The applicant must pay all cost associated with the installation of the lighting infrastructure and shall be responsible for all energy cost associated with the lights for a period not less than one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 04-23, 11-18-04) 
Sec. 20-67. - Severability. 
If any provision of this article or application thereof to any person or circumstance, shall be held to be invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity shall not affect the other provisions, or application thereof, of this article, which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end, the provisions of this article are hereby declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 04-23, 11-18-04) 
Sec. 20-68. - Effective date. 
This article shall become effective immediately upon enactment. 
(Ord. No. 04-23, 11-18-04) 
Secs. 20-69, 20-70. - Reserved.

Chapter 21 - WATER, SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; provisions relative to water and sewerage in subdivisions, § 20.3-70 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Definitions. 
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
Consumer: Any person, establishment, unit or space served on or through any water meter other than the customer in whose name the meter is listed or from whom payment may be required. 
Customer: The owner of the property served by a water connection, or the tenant, lessee, renter, establishment or occupant of such property, or the person in or against whose name the water connection for such property is listed on the books and records of the city, and who is responsible to the city for payment of bills incurred for water furnished to such property and for use by such property of the public sewer system of the city, either or both. 
Maximum monthly bill: The fixed minimum monthly payment required for a water meter or connection calculated under the provisions of this chapter. 
Multiple meter: Any water meter through which more than one (1) family, establishment, space or unit is served. 
User: A water customer as above defined whose property also discharges sewage, wastes or water into the public sanitary sewer system of the city in any quantity. 
Utility: Water, sewer service, garbage and/or trash. 
(Ord. No. 85-15, 11-26-85) 
Sec. 21-2. - Scope of provisions. 
All pertinent provisions of this chapter are hereby made a part of the terms and conditions whereby the city shall furnish any utility service to any person, or whereby the city shall make any utility connections or perform any work of any kind in connection with the furnishing of any utility service pursuant to the rules and regulations of the mayor and council. 
Sec. 21-3. - Service to comply with technical provisions. 
Any utility service furnished under the provisions of this chapter shall be in accordance with and in compliance with all applicable technical provisions of this Code, state law and city ordinances, rules and regulations. 
Sec. 21-4. - Rules, regulations. 
The mayor and council shall have the authority to establish by rule or regulation such standards and specifications as may be deemed necessary for the installation, construction and maintenance of any utility service system owned and operated by the city within or without the city and under the management of the mayor and council. Such rules, regulations, standards and specifications shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. Violation of such rules, regulations, standards and specifications shall be deemed a violation of a city ordinance. 
State Law reference— Standards for on-site sewage management systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-2-7; authority for acquisition construction, operation and maintenance of municipal water and sewage systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5. 
Sec. 21-5. - Inspection outside city. 
In order to protect the utility service supply, the city will not make any water or sewer taps or connections outside the city limits until the premises involved has been inspected and approved by the plumbing inspector. 
Sec. 21-6. - Right of entry. 
Any authorized inspector of the city shall have free access at any time to all premises supplied with any utility service by the city for the purpose of examination in order to protect the utility services from abusive use. 
(Ord. No. 73-2, § 11, 3-1-73) 
Sec. 21-7. - Termination of service authorized. 
The city shall have the right to disconnect or refuse to connect or reconnect any utility service for the following reasons: 
(1)	Failure to meet the applicable provisions of law; 
(2)	Violation of the rules and regulations pertaining to utility service; 
(3)	Nonpayment of bills; 
(4)	Willful or negligent waste of service due to improper or imperfect pipes, fixtures, appliances or otherwise; 
(5)	Molesting any meter, seal or other equipment controlling or regulating the supply of utility service; 
(6)	Theft or diversion and/or use of service without payment therefor; 
(7)	Vacancy of premises. 
Sec. 21-8. - Liability of city for damage. 
The city shall not be liable for any damage to any customer of any utility service furnished by the city due to backflow of the sewerage system, failure of supply, interruption of service or any other cause outside the direct control of the city. 
Sec. 21-9. - Utility service—Application required. 
Any person desiring any utility service furnished by the city shall make application for the same to the mayor and council. Such application shall contain the applicant's name, address and the uses for which such utility service is desired. 
Sec. 21-10. - Same—Not available to debtors. 
The city may decline or fail or cease to furnish utility service to any person who may be in debt to the city for any reason, except ad valorem taxes and special assessments. 
Sec. 21-11. - Same—Charges for initial water service; connections to system. 
(a)	Customer to pay; city to provide material, service, inspection. Each consumer (residential, commercial, institutional or industrial) subscribing to use the water service of the city shall pay a tapping or connection fee as established in subsection (e) below. The city administrator shall reserve the right to prorate tap fees under certain circumstances. 
For the tapping fee the city will tap the main, provide and install the corporate stop and curb stop meter, couplings, backup or check valve, and meter box; the service line between the distribution main and meter will be installed (paid for) by the permittee, including all labor, equipment, materials, excavation, backfilling and street repair. The city will provide inspection and the permittee will be responsible for all workmanship to install the service line. The permittee may contract with the city for the installation of the service line. 
(b)	Distribution lines. The permittee will provide a service line from the distribution line to the property line where the distribution line exists or is to be connected, and run immediately adjacent and parallel to the property to be served. Where no distribution line exists, extension of the main shall be provided by permittee at permittee's expense, all such extensions being subject to the requirements, inspection and approval of the city. The extended main shall become the property of the city. The materials and workmanship for the extension shall be guaranteed for one (1) year from date of final acceptance and any defects shall be repaired at no expense to the city. After the warranty period the city shall provide maintenance for the main extension to the property line. 
(c)	Installation of meters larger than one and one-half inches. For meters larger than one and one-half (1½) inches the city will determine the size required for each particular service based on information provided by the residential, commercial, institutional or industrial concern or developer requiring service. The permittee shall purchase the meter from the city, provide all materials, (piping, valves, couplings, meter box, bypass, etc.) equipment and labor to install the service line from the tap made to the property line and install the meter. Tap fees are shown below. Plans and specifications for the service shall be submitted to the city for review. The permittee's contractor for the work shall be subject to approval by the city. The construction work shall conform to the city's requirements and shall be subject to inspection and approval by the city. Work and materials shall be guaranteed for one (1) year from actual final acceptance and any defects shall be required at no expense to the city. The service line from the distribution main to the water meter shall be the property of the city. After the warranty period, the city shall provide maintenance of the service line from main to meter or to the property line. 
(d)	Provisions do not commit city. Nothing in this section shall commit the city to install mains, extend mains, or provide backfilling and restoration when such installation extension is required. 
(e)	Tapping fees—Water. The following tap fees are established (including meter): ;$; 
Hotel, motels, inns—Initial connection expansion\6,750.00 
Office, retail shops, commercial, and industrial: 
Three-fourths inch by five-eighths inch meter\450.00 
One-inch meter\562.00 
Two-inch meter\750.00 
Three-inch meter\1,875.00 
Four-inch meter\3,750.00 
Six-inch meter\7,050.00 
Eight-inch meter\8,700.00 
Any residential, commercial, institutional, or industrial structure that requires a tap for water service for fire protection must pay an additional fee based on the size of the tap-in line: 
Three-inch meter\1,875.00 
Four-inch meter\3,750.00 
Six-inch meter\7,050.00 
Eight-inch meter\8,700.00 ;\$; 
(f)	Each water connection shall require four (4) inspections—locate, initial, open trench and final. The cost of these inspections shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). There shall also be an inspection of the Omni marker for a cost of twelve dollars and fifty cents ($12.50). 
(Ord. No. 86-4, 2-13-86; Ord. No. 94-7, 9-8-94; Ord. No. 97-10, 7-16-97; Ord. No. 02-14, 12-12-02; Ord. No. 09-16, 9-24-09) 
Sec. 21-12. - Same—Use assumed. 
All premises connected to any utility service of the city shall be assumed to be using such utility service and the owner or occupant shall be charged therefor so long as such premises remain connected with the utility service. 
Sec. 21-13. - Same—Not to use contrary to permit. 
Any person having a permit from the city for the use of any utility service offered by the city who shall use such utility service for any purpose other than mentioned in such permit or who shall make any unauthorized changes in such service shall be deemed guilty of a violation of city ordinance. 
Sec. 21-14. - Damage, trespass of equipment. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, not having authority to do so, to open any water hydrant or tamper with any utility service furnished by the city to consumers, or to in any other way molest, damage or trespass upon any equipment or premises belonging to the city connected with any utility service. 
Sec. 21-15. - Temporary interruption of service. 
The city reserves the right to cut off any utility service without notice in case of emergencies. When an interruption in service is necessary for the maintenance and improvement of the utility system, affected customers will be notified as circumstances permit. 
Sec. 21-16. - Restricting use. 
The city hereby reserves the right to at any time restrict or prevent the use of any utility service furnished by the city during periods of emergency or circumstances demanding such restriction or prevention of use. 
Sec. 21-17. - Sale of service by customer. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to resell any utility service obtained from the city to others except by special arrangement with the mayor and council. 
Sec. 21-18. - Meters. 
Meters for the measurement of utility service furnished by the city shall be furnished and installed by, and shall remain the property of, the city. 
Sec. 21-19. - Deposits required. 
Along with the application for utility service, the applicant is required for residential service to pay the city a deposit in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). For commercial service, the applicant is required to pay to the city a deposit in the amount of the estimated invoice for two (2) months water and sewer service to be calculated by the mayor and council and/or their designee and determined using the water consumption table in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 02-10, 11-14-02) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 02-10, adopted Nov. 14, 2002, repealed § 21-19 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 21-19 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 73-2, § 1, adopted March 1, 1973; Ord. No. 86-23, adopted Nov. 13, 1986; Ord. No. 88-6, adopted June 9, 1988; and Ord. No. 92-13, adopted Oct. 22, 1992. 
Sec. 21-20. - Refund of deposit. 
Refunds of deposits made for utility service shall be made upon the termination of such utility service only after payment of all indebtedness to the city for such utility service. Application of deposit may be made in partial or total settlement of accounts when supply is cut off for nonpayment of a bill, or for any infraction or violation of any ordinance, rule or regulation of the city relative to utility services offered by the city. 
(Ord. No. 73-2, § 2, 3-1-73) 
Sec. 21-21. - Determination of charges of water and sewage systems—Adopted. 
The City of Port Wentworth shall prescribe, revise and collect rates, fees, tolls or charges for the services, facilities or commodities furnished to persons or users or property. When services are available but not used, the maximum rates, fees, tolls, or other charges imposed shall not exceed the minimum charge or fee imposed on a user of such system. 
(Ord. No. 86-7, 5-22-86) 
Sec. 21-22. - Same—When payment due. 
All bills for utility services furnished by the city shall be due and payable when rendered or as negotiated by the mayor and council or their designee. 
(Ord. No. 02-14, 12-12-02) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 02-14, adopted Dec. 12, 2002, repealed § 21-22, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 21-22 pertained to charges for initial water service; connection to system, and derived from Ord. No. 73-2, §§ 2, 3, adopted March 1, 1973; and Ord. No. 01-11, adopted April 26, 2001. 
Sec. 21-23. - Penalty for failure to pay; disconnection. 
(a)	Penalty for failure to pay. In the event any consumer of utility services furnished by the city fails to pay their bill therefor by the last working day of the month in which they are billed, a penalty of ten (10) percent of the delinquent statement shall be added thereto. 
(b)	Disconnection for nonpayment. In the event any consumer of utility services furnished by the city fails to pay his bill, the nonpayment of billing within forty-five (45) days from date due will result in disconnection of water service. The city may order termination of all utilities as a result of nonpayment of any service. 
(Ord. No. 73-2, §§ 3—6, 3-1-73; Ord. No. 85-16, 11-26-85; Ord. No. 12-34, § 1, 8-23-12) 
Sec. 21-24. - Collection of inactive unpaid utility accounts. 
(a)	The mayor and council of the City of Port Wentworth shall employ a collection agency to collect on inactive unpaid utility accounts. Accounts to be turned over for collection shall be those at least ninety (90) days past due with a balance of not less than twenty-five ($25.00). 
(b)	All uncollected utility accounts still outstanding at the end of the fiscal year after attempts of collection have been made shall be presented to mayor and council to be written off. 
(Ord. No. 04-05, 3-25-04; Ord. No. 10-26, 9-24-10) 
Sec. 21-25. - Reconnection after disconnection. 
In the event a utility service is disconnected for nonpayment of the bill, the consumer thereof shall have the right to have the same reconnected only upon the payment of the amount due and a reconnection fee in such amount as set by mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 73-2, § 7, 3-1-73; Ord. No. 92-8, 6-11-92) 
Sec. 21-26. - Voluntary discontinuance of service. 
Consumers wishing to discontinue the use of any utility service shall give written notice thereof at the city hall. Failure to do so shall render them liable for the payment of all bills until such notice has been given. 
Sec. 21-27. - Maintenance of system by consumer. 
The consumer of water service furnished by the city shall maintain and keep in good repair all connections, appliances and other apparatus installed and used in connection with such service. 
Sec. 21-28. - Responsibility of real estate developers for water and sewer system installation, easements, etc.
